Hi Mahira! I’m doing well thanks, isolating here in my house in London. I’m glad you’re well and safe and that you have been able to carry on with the animation. If you want to show me I’d happy to have a look at it!

It’s important to do character design as you learn to observe and simplify the shapes, and it’s good as you push your creativity as well.

Background Designer (layout and paint) is usually a role that is required in 2D productions, like tv shows or features like Klaus. It’s a production department role, so it’s usually fast paced and require a lot of work, can be less creative as you receive the design package/bible and direction, so it can also be very technical.

The environment designer is more creative role ( in fact can be pre-production role in the art department) he can add ideas and develop the show, it’s both technical (you have to have the basis like perspective, design appeal, understanding of 3D volumes etc) and creative (you can play with the shapes, come up with fun solutions and experiment a bit more). Sometimes tho the environment designer is not asked to use the colors as it will be done in production by others.
